criteria.name: Perspective Authenticity
criteria.description: Are roles represented genuinely without strawman arguments?

scale.1: Roles are caricatures or strawmen. Positions feel artificial or dismissive ('X just wants...'). No genuine advocacy.
scale.2: Some roles feel authentic but others are weak. Uneven representation. Some strawmanning present.
scale.3: Most roles feel genuine. Positions are reasonable but may lack depth. Minimal strawmanning.
scale.4: All roles authentically represented. Each is 'hero of their own story.' Steelman approach evident. Strong advocacy for each perspective.
scale.5: Exceptional authenticity. Every role's position is compellingly argued. Reader could genuinely support any perspective. Intellectual empathy demonstrated throughout.

criteria.name: Depth of Roleplay
criteria.description: Are priorities, concerns, evidence, and vulnerabilities fully articulated for each role?

scale.1: Roles are one-dimensional. Only positions stated, no priorities, concerns, or evidence.
scale.2: Positions and some priorities stated. Concerns and evidence missing or thin.
scale.3: Positions, priorities, and concerns articulated. Evidence present but may be thin. Vulnerabilities rarely acknowledged.
scale.4: Comprehensive roleplay. Clear position, well-justified priorities, specific concerns, supporting evidence, and acknowledged vulnerabilities for each role.
scale.5: Exceptionally deep roleplay. Rich detail on priorities, nuanced concerns, strong evidence, intellectual honesty about vulnerabilities and limits. Success metrics defined for each role.

criteria.name: Debate Quality
criteria.description: Do perspectives genuinely clash on key points of disagreement?

scale.1: No actual debate. Roles present positions but don't engage. Talking past each other or premature consensus.
scale.2: Limited engagement. Some responses to other roles but mostly separate monologues. Key tensions not surfaced.
scale.3: Moderate debate. Roles respond to each other on main points. Some clash evident but could go deeper.
scale.4: Strong debate. Perspectives directly engage on 3-5 key dimensions. Real clash of ideas. Tensions clearly surfaced.
scale.5: Exceptional debate. Deep engagement with point-counterpoint structure. All major tensions explored thoroughly. Debate format (devil's advocate, crux-finding, etc.) skillfully applied.

criteria.name: Tension Surfacing
criteria.description: Are irreducible tradeoffs and conflicts explicitly identified?

scale.1: No tensions identified. Falsely suggests all perspectives align. Missing the point of debate.
scale.2: Some tensions mentioned but not explored. Glossed over or minimized.
scale.3: Main tensions identified (2-3 key tradeoffs). Reasonably clear where perspectives conflict.
scale.4: All major tensions surfaced and explored. Clear on irreducible tradeoffs (speed vs quality, cost vs flexibility, etc.). Dimensions of disagreement explicit.
scale.5: Comprehensive tension mapping. All conflicts identified, categorized, and explored deeply. False dichotomies challenged. Genuine irreducible tradeoffs distinguished from resolvable disagreements.

criteria.name: Crux Identification
criteria.description: Are conditions that would change each role's mind identified?

scale.1: No cruxes identified. Positions appear fixed and immovable.
scale.2: Vague acknowledgment that positions could change but no specifics.
scale.3: Some cruxes identified for some roles. Moderate specificity on what would change minds.
scale.4: Clear cruxes for all roles. Specific conditions or evidence that would shift positions. Enables productive focus on key uncertainties.
scale.5: Exceptional crux identification. Specific, testable conditions for each role. Distinguishes between cruxes (truly pivotal) and nice-to-haves. Debate explicitly focuses on resolving cruxes.

criteria.name: Synthesis Coherence
criteria.description: Is the unified recommendation logical, well-integrated, and addresses the decision?

scale.1: No synthesis. Just restates positions or says 'we need more information.' Avoids deciding.
scale.2: Weak synthesis. Either 'do everything' (no prioritization) or 'X wins, Y loses' (dismisses perspectives). Not truly integrated.
scale.3: Moderate synthesis. Clear recommendation but integration is shallow. May not fully address all concerns or explain tradeoffs.
scale.4: Strong synthesis. Coherent recommendation that integrates insights from all perspectives. Integration pattern clear (weighted, sequencing, conditional, hybrid, reframing, constraint elevation). Addresses decision directly.
scale.5: Exceptional synthesis. Deeply integrated recommendation better than any single perspective. Pattern expertly applied. Innovative solution that satisfies multiple objectives. Elegant and actionable.

criteria.name: Concern Integration
criteria.description: Are each role's core concerns explicitly addressed in the synthesis?

scale.1: No concern integration. Synthesis ignores or dismisses most perspectives' concerns.
scale.2: Limited integration. Addresses concerns from 1-2 roles, ignores others.
scale.3: Moderate integration. Most roles' main concerns acknowledged but may not be fully addressed. Some perspectives feel under-represented.
scale.4: Strong integration. All roles' core concerns explicitly addressed. Clear explanation of how synthesis handles each perspective's priorities.
scale.5: Exceptional integration. Every role's concerns not just addressed but shown to be *strengthened* by the integrated approach. Synthesis makes each perspective better off than going solo.

criteria.name: Tradeoff Transparency
criteria.description: Are accepted tradeoffs and rejected alternatives clearly explained?

scale.1: No tradeoff transparency. Synthesis presented as 'best of all worlds' without acknowledging costs.
scale.2: Minimal transparency. Vague acknowledgment that tradeoffs exist but not specified.
scale.3: Moderate transparency. Main tradeoffs mentioned. Some explanation of what's being accepted/rejected.
scale.4: Strong transparency. Clear on what's prioritized and what's sacrificed. Explicit rationale for tradeoffs. Alternatives rejected with reasons.
scale.5: Exceptional transparency. Comprehensive accounting of all tradeoffs. Clear on second-order effects. Honest about what each perspective gives up and why it's worth it. 'What we're NOT doing' as clear as 'What we ARE doing.'

criteria.name: Actionability
criteria.description: Are next steps specific, feasible, with owners and timelines?

scale.1: No action plan. Vague or missing next steps.
scale.2: Vague next steps. 'Consider X', 'Explore Y.' No owners or timelines.
scale.3: Moderate actionability. Next steps identified but lack detail on who/when/how. Success metrics missing or vague.
scale.4: Strong actionability. Clear next steps with owners and dates. Success metrics defined. Implementation approach specified (phased, conditional, etc.).
scale.5: Exceptional actionability. Detailed implementation plan. Owners assigned, timeline clear, milestones defined, success metrics from each role's perspective, monitoring plan, escalation conditions, decision review cadence.

criteria.name: Stakeholder Readiness
criteria.description: Is synthesis communicated appropriately for different audiences?

scale.1: No stakeholder tailoring. Single narrative that may not resonate with any audience.
scale.2: Minimal tailoring. One-size-fits-all communication. May be too technical for execs or too vague for implementers.
scale.3: Moderate tailoring. Some audience awareness. Key messages identified but not fully adapted.
scale.4: Strong tailoring. Synthesis clearly communicates to different stakeholders (exec summary, technical detail, operational guidance). Appropriate emphasis for each audience.
scale.5: Exceptional tailoring. Multiple versions or sections for different stakeholders. Executive summary for leaders, technical appendix for specialists, operational guide for implementation teams. Anticipates questions from each audience.

simple_decisions.description: Binary choices with 2-3 clear stakeholders (e.g., build vs buy, speed vs quality). Acceptable to have simpler analysis (criteria 3-4).

standard_decisions.description: Multi-faceted decisions with 3-4 stakeholders and competing priorities (e.g., product roadmap, hiring strategy, market entry). Standard threshold applies (criteria average ≥3.5).

complex_decisions.description: Strategic decisions with 4-5+ stakeholders, power dynamics, and high stakes (e.g., company strategy, major pivots, organizational change). Higher bar required (criteria average ≥4.0).

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Roles are caricatured or weakly represented. 'X just wants shiny tech', 'Y only cares about money.'
common_failure_modes.fix: Steelman approach: Present the *strongest* version of each perspective. Each role is 'hero of their own story.' If a position feels weak, strengthen it.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Roles agree too quickly without genuine debate. 'We all want the same thing.'
common_failure_modes.fix: Play devil's advocate. Ask: 'What could go wrong?' 'Where do you disagree?' Test agreement with edge cases. Give permission to disagree.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Roles present positions but don't engage. Arguments on different dimensions (one says cost, other says speed).
common_failure_modes.fix: Make dimensions of disagreement explicit. Force direct engagement: '[Role A], respond to [Role B]'s point about X.'

common_failure_modes.symptoms: 'Either X or we fail.' 'We must choose between quality and speed.'
common_failure_modes.fix: Challenge the dichotomy. Explore middle ground, sequencing, conditional strategies. Ask: 'Are those really the only two options?'

common_failure_modes.symptoms: 'X wins, Y loses.' Some roles' concerns ignored or minimized in synthesis.
common_failure_modes.fix: Explicitly address every role's core concerns. Show how synthesis incorporates (not dismisses) each perspective. Check: 'Does this address your concern about [issue]?'

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Synthesis presented as win-win without acknowledging costs. No transparency on what's sacrificed.
common_failure_modes.fix: Make tradeoffs explicit. 'We're prioritizing X, accepting Y, rejecting Z because [rationale].' Be honest about costs.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: 'We need more information.' Endless debate without convergence. Perfect information fallacy.
common_failure_modes.fix: Set decision deadline. Clarify decision criteria. Good-enough threshold. Explicitly trade off value of info vs cost of delay.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: One role speaks 70%+ of time. Others defer. Synthesis reflects single perspective.
common_failure_modes.fix: Explicit turn-taking. Direct questions to quieter roles. Affirm their contributions. Check power dynamics.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Synthesis is conceptual but not actionable. No clear next steps, owners, or timeline.
common_failure_modes.fix: Specify: Who does what by when? How do we measure success? What's the implementation approach (phased, conditional)? When do we review?

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Same explanation for execs, engineers, and operators. Too technical or too vague for some.
common_failure_modes.fix: Tailor communication. Exec summary (strategic), technical brief (implementation), operational guide (execution). Emphasize what each audience cares about.

usage_notes: Use this rubric to self-assess before delivering synthesis. For simple binary decisions, 3.0+ is acceptable. For standard multi-stakeholder decisions, aim for 3.5+. For complex strategic decisions with high stakes, aim for 4.0+. Pay special attention to Perspective Authenticity, Synthesis Coherence, and Concern Integration as these are most critical for effective roleplay-debate-synthesis.
